name: haliaeetus-leucocephalus
definition: A North American eagle characterized by a brownish-black body and a white head and tail in the adult.
description:
The bald eagle is a bird of prey found in North America.

Bald eagles are not actually bald; the name derives from an older meaning of the word, "white headed".

The plumage of an adult bald eagle is evenly dark brown with a white head and tail.

The beak is large and hooked. The tail is moderately long and slightly wedge-shaped.

The sexes are identical in plumage coloration, but sexual dimorphism is evident in the species, in that females are 25% larger than males.

Immature eagles are dark, and until they are about five years old, they lack the distinctive white markings that make their parents so easy to identify.

Its range includes most of Canada and Alaska, all of the contiguous United States, and northern Mexico.

Bald eagles prefer living in areas close to bodies of water, as their favorite prey is fish.

They can be found in wetlands, on the coasts, near lakes or rivers, and in marshes.

The vast majority of a bald eagle’s diet consists of fish.

Many populations will rely heavily on the spawning behaviors of fish, like salmon and trout for their diet.

These powerful birds of prey use their talons to fish, but they get many of their meals by scavenging carrion or stealing the kills of other animals.

Sexual maturity is attained at the age of four to five years.

Bald eagles are believed to mate for life.

They build the largest nest of any North American bird and the largest tree nests ever recorded for any animal species.

The nest is up to 4 meters deep, 2.5 meters wide, and has one metric ton in weight.

Compared to most other raptors bald eagles are early breeders: nest building is by mid-February, egg laying is often late February, and incubation is usually mid-March and early May.

Eggs hatch from mid April to early May, and the young fledge late June to early July.

Both the male and female take turns incubating the eggs, but the female does most of the sitting.

The parent not incubating will hunt for food or look for nesting material during this stage.

In the late 20th century it was on the brink of extirpation in the contiguous United States.

Populations have since recovered and the species was removed from the U.S. government's list of endangered species on July 12, 1995 and transferred to the list of threatened species.

It was removed from the List of Endangered and Threatened Wildlife in the contiguous states on June 28, 2007.

The bald eagle is the national bird of the United States of America. The bald eagle appears on its seal.

featured.caption: The bald eagle is an opportunistic feeder which subsists mainly on fish, which it swoops down and snatches from the water with its talons.

facts.name: Bald eagles are not bald at all
facts.value: Bald eagles are not bald at all. Eagle looks "bald" because white feathers on the head are in contrast with dark brown feathers on the rest of the body.

facts.name: They live 28 years in the wild
facts.value: They live 28 years in the wild and up to 36 years in captivity.

facts.name: On national emblem of the United States
facts.value: Bald eagle has been national emblem of the United States ever since 1782.

facts.name: Adult eagles are 91 cm tall
facts.value: Adult eagles are 91 cm tall and weigh up to 4 kg. Females are larger than males.

facts.name: Bald eagles are monogamous
facts.value: Bald eagles are monogamous, which means that one pair of eagles stays together for the rest of their life.

facts.name: Their wingspan is up to 2.2 m
facts.value: Their wingspan ranges from 1.6 to 2.2 meters.

facts.name: Bald eagles build large nests
facts.value: Bald eagles build large nests. Largest known nest was 6 meters deep, 4 meters wide and weighed nearly 3 tones.

facts.name: Steal hunt from other birds or even humans
facts.value: Bald eagles will steal hunt from other birds or even humans (during fishing) thanks to their speed and sharp claws.

facts.name: They eat fish
facts.value: They eat fish, other birds, muskrats and turtles. Hooked beak helps them tear apart their prey.

facts.name: They have excellent eyesight
facts.value: They have excellent eyesight and see things 4-7 times better than humans.

facts.name: Bald eagles fly 50 kmh
facts.value: Bald eagles fly 50 kilometers per hour. When they "dive" through the air to catch the prey, they can reach 160 kilometers per hour.

facts.name: Breathe air using the holes on their beaks
facts.value: Bald eagles breathe air using the holes on their beaks called "nares".

facts.name: Bald eagle don't have vocal cords
facts.value: Although they don't have vocal cords, they use sounds to communicate. They produce squeaking and screeching sounds by pushing the air through the bones in their neck.

facts.name: They have around 7000 feathers
facts.value: They have around 7000 feathers. They are light, but strong.

facts.name: Young birds are dark in color
facts.value: Young birds are dark in color. When they turn 5 years, they will start resembling their parents.

related.definition: The Andean condor is a South American bird in the New World vulture family Cathartidae and is the only member of the genus Vultur.
A very large vulture found in the southern California mountains that was nearly extinct.
A large eagle of the Northern Hemisphere, having dark plumage with brownish-yellow feathers on the back of the head and neck.
The northern goshawk is a medium-large raptor in the family Accipitridae, which also includes eagles, buzzards and harriers.
The black kite  is a medium-sized bird of prey in the family Accipitridae, which also includes many other diurnal raptors.
